ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned more Chinese, specifically more grammatical structures, more words, better comprehension, and improving tones.
Learned new vocabulary and grammar. Improved my oral skills and tones by speaking in class everyday. Wrote my first short essays in Chinese.
Reading, writing, speaking and understanding Chinese.
Verbal language practice, essay writing, listening comprehension.
I improved my fluency and comfort speaking Chinese, as well as my reading ability and vocabulary.
Developed my practical skills in speaking Mandarin Chinese
The course uses a lot of great materials and is paced very well to learn a lot while still gaining a solid understanding of the content!

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The only area for improvement to me is that the textbook is a bit outdated, and needs to either be updated or changed so that we're learning language that is useful for the 21st century.
Strenght: good syllabus with requiring the student to stay on top of their studies everyday. Weakness: asynchronous day work took more than the class time would've taken (50 min)
I wouldnt change anything. The class was very fun and engaging.

The course schedule was very effective in keeping me constantly engaged with the language but the textbook was outdated and included some vocabulary that is not that relevant/useful. Sometimes wish we could have an in-depth explanation on some grammar rules instead of  repeating sentence patterns.
Asynchronous was more inconvenient, took up more time than the class equivalent. Did not find much use in the weekly required tutorials.

strengths: lots of talking and practicing in class; all the homework was super helpful for learning; much of the vocabulary felt relevant to real life; really fun atmosphere; fast-paced but not too fast to follow so it really helped develop listening comprehension

weaknesses: although the presentations we did were fun and useful for speaking practice, I thought the handwritten essay was more helpful for learning characters; maybe doing a presentation every third essay and handwriting it more often would be helpful
Wang laoshi is amazing and did a great job helping Liao Laoshi teach us as well.

Strengths: I feel like I've progressed a lot in a semester, the course covers lots of material, teaching is fantastic
Weaknesses: There could be less of a focus on reciting the lesson text and more on generating sentences ourselves. Re: homework, I found the translation exercises in L1 and L2 very helpful for grammar and there could have been more of that.
The course has a great learning atmosphere in small groups. While it is an entertaining time, I also learned A LOT!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! The Chinese department is great, and you really continue bettering your Chinese ability in the class. It has a solid amount of work, but it's necessary to learn the language. There isn't any unnecessary work, and I doubt the program would work without the work.
Yes because the Chinese Department at Yale is excellent, and because this course allows you to effectively learn Chinese.
It is a huge time commitment but a great way of learning Chinese if you are really willing to put in the time and effort.
Yes, you are sure to improve your Mandarin language skill as long as you can commit enough time to do all the homework everyday.
yes, it was both really helpful for my Chinese and also really fun; I always looked forward to class
yes -- especially with Wang Laoshi.
Yes, it provided lots of opportunities to practice speaking, and introduced many new vocabulary and grammar concepts. It does move fast, so be sure to review as the lessons go on.
